title: Three Ways to Make Code School Work for You
summary: Three tips for making the most out of a code school education.
body:
TINKER

You’ve read about how code schools are changing the face of technology education, making up for the lack of computer science majors coming out of traditional Universities. You’re creative and love to learn, and you also know your college major has helped you find a ‘job’ more than a ‘career.’ You’ve been told that 12 weeks of time away from work in an intensive code school will be worth it in the long run, but it’s still  a leap of faith. How do you determine if a code school program is right for you? In a word, tinker.

Tinkering is the act of playing around, teaching yourself, figuring out on your own how to solve a problem, ‘Googling’ it. It’s one of the most important attributes employers are looking for when they hire programmers. To help begin your tinkering adventure, we’ve collected some gems from the plethora of (mostly free) coding tutorials available online. These resources, and language descriptions, are specific to the technologies that will be taught in our Academy courses and may not apply to all code schools. Leave us a comment at the end of this article if you find anything noteworthy along the way.

HTML/CSS

HTML & CSS are used to define the elements (headers, paragraphs, etc.) and presentation of a website. These are front end languages and components. Front end engineering is the creation of an interface that allows the user and back end to communicate, it is essentially the appearance and interactivity of a website. Try Dash, a slide-based text and interactive tutorials (i.e. entering code in a window or screen). Dash lets you tinker with several small projects: a personal website, a responsible blog theme, a small business website, and a CSS robot. Dash incorporates JavaScript as well as HTML & CSS.

JavaScript 

JavaScript, another front end language, is used to make pages more interactive. It is used with other languages such as HTML to make the visual components more dynamic. Try Codecademy and use interactive tutorials to create interactive websites and browser based games.

Ruby on Rails

Ruby is modular, object-oriented programming language. Rails is a full-stack open source web application framework. This means that it allows pages and applications to pull information from the server and talk directly to the database.This back end language is open source and scalable, so it is able to be used on projects of varying sizes. Also, websites and applications built using Rails can be deployed quickly. Try Code School ‘s videos and interactive Ruby tutorials with challenges to learn to build dynamic web applications.

iOS

Objective-C is the programming language of the iOS operating system of Apple products. Try Code School‘s videos and interactive iOS tutorials starting with basic iOS development in Objective-C.

Now, perhaps you’re thinking, “If you just gave me all of these free coding tutorial websites, why should I enroll in a code school?” We hope you’ll check out these online sites to give you an understanding of what you could be learning in depth at The Academy. Online code education is a great start! However, like learning a foreign language, you need to completely immerse yourself to become fluent. It is very difficult to fully understand development’s complex subject matter and nuances from a website tutorial or YouTube video. In real world programming there can be multiple ‘acceptable’ methods to execute a command. Learning how to navigate the subjectivity of software engineering is a benefit that The Academy provides in a classroom setting: unscripted, open ended assignments that set you up to make judgments within the subjectivity of the field. The  curriculum provides a fundamental understanding of complex steps and explains why things work the way they do, giving you the tools and experience needed to succeed after classes end. A code school experience will also provide the guidance of experts and the added benefit of having access to real-time culture and collaboration in an entrepreneurial and technical environment .

CHOOSE WISELY

When it comes to code schools, there are several variations. In terms of curriculum, some programs focus intensely on learning a specific language or highly related set of languages while other programs provide a general, less focused, overview of many technologies. Neither is wrong or right, it simply depends on your goal. If you are hoping to leave the class with a job as a professional programmer, than you should look into the first option. Alternatively, courses touching on numerous languages provide an excellent technical foundation for people in non-programming roles in a technical environment, such as sales, marketing, technical writing, or operations.

There is perhaps greater disparity in graduate satisfaction between part-time and full-time programs. Part time programs allow for students to continue their everyday life while getting a code school education. Students divide their time between their weekday job and code school, which is on evenings and/or weekends. This type of study allows for flexibility, but not for complete and undivided immersion into the subject matter. Students of part time programs should be realistic about whether this type of program will set them up for success as a professional programmer.

Full time programs, on the other hand, mean that the program essentially becomes a student’s day job, and then some. These programs allow for the curriculum to be intensive and fully immersive because students won’t have outside distractions or side projects demanding their concentration and time in addition to schoolwork. Students of full-time programs tend to have a much more positive experience – both in securing a job and possessing the abilities to do the job – post code school.

Before making the (often life changing) decision to attend a code school, ask yourself the following questions to help determine the right program for you:

  • What are your career goals?
  • Which style of learning best suits your needs?
  • What serves the best purpose for your future?

GET NOTICED

Effective code schools offer guest lectures, vetted instructors, networking events, freelance work, office tours, free tutoring, and other opportunities that help you get face time with employers and local stakeholders. Make sure your school has solid ties with area employers – typically this comes in the form of an employer advisory board or hiring partners – and take advantage by introducing yourself and asking questions. Collect emails from employers and ask if you can send them samples of your work. Write a blog. Attend office tours and events held off-campus, and chat with employees to see how they like working there. Employers are involved with code academies because they are hoping to hire you and made a difference in the community.

Remember, there’s a lack of qualified programmers across the country. Carpe diem!
